dialogues.speaker: PONTIAC
dialogues.text: is parked at the curb. It waits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: looks at his watch. With his meticulously parted red hair might be a bank president. It's 6:55 a.m.

dialogues.speaker: HAMILTON
dialogues.text: Time. Thirty year old JOHN HERBERT DILLINGER is in the backseat nods. His arms are behind him. We don't know why. Red sta the car and drives forward.

dialogues.speaker: CONVICTS
dialogues.text: Its cold.-Convicts' uniforms are broadly striped and fray This is a line of hard men branded by prison: shorn hair, broken nose, eyes with a cold ferocity. And their aggress has a nihilistic edge; their spirits never surrender. The nothing beaten down about these men. Like Alcatraz, Leavenworth, and Sing Sing, this is the end of the line.

dialogues.speaker: PRISON GUARDS
dialogues.text: in visored black caps, black shirts, black patent leather Browne belts with three-foot long billy clubs watch the l poised to unleash violence. AMONG THE HARD MEN ARE... HARRY "PETE" PIERPONT (32), 6 foot 1 with eerie blue eyes Brilliant, violent, he hates all authority. CHARLES MAKLEY ( 44), squat with an anvil jaw, facial sca and as calm as Pierpont is volatile. HOMER VAN METER (27), tall, an incorrigible clown and an unemotional killer. He has continued to ridicule guards e when it cost him months in the hole.

dialogues.speaker: THESE THREE
dialogues.text: with an older man, WALTER DIETRICH, wait for the lam. wor call to the prison Shirt Factory...

dialogues.text: watches through a window as a Pontiac pulls into the park area in front of the prison across from the streetcar tra Hamilton jerks a handcuffed Dillinger out of the backseat Dillinger is shoved forward. Hamilton's wearing a star.

dialogues.speaker: TURNKEY
dialogues.text: (opening up) Afternoon. Hamilton flashes the badge. He shoves Dillinger inside. I adjacent room FIVE GUARDS play poker. Next to them is a barred entrance to the prison yard. As the cage door lock behind him, this is the last place Dillinger wants to hav entered. Meanwhile...

dialogues.speaker: BOXES
dialogues.text: and bolts of fabric wait for the convicts. lam. A KLAXON sounds. Door opens. Convicts enter. Walter Dietrich goes right to the stacks and pulls a box with an "X" crayoned the side. Its labeled "Thread." (Dietrich was mentored by Herbert K. Lamm, an ex-Prussian soldier who invented professional bank robbery by applyin military tactics and who rode with Butch & Sundanc4's the Wall Gang in Utah in 1901. in prison Dietrich passed Lamm's techniques. His brightest student in 1933 is..'ohn Herbert Dillinger.)

dialogues.speaker: TURNKEY
dialogues.text: . John... Johnnie Dillinger?

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: That's right. But my friends call me "Johnnie". You gotta address me as "Mister" Dillinger. Dillinger's insubordination puzzles Turnkey so he doesn't Hamilton bat a Thompson submachine gun across the back of head and swing it onto the Two Guards...

dialogues.text: Against the wall! Hands up! Get up! Dillinger's cuffs fell away. Now his Thompson covers the stunned pokerГ‚В°players. Hamilton and Dillinger are as t they come.- They share their food, money, liquor, ammunit and women. ,.id right now...

dialogues.text: is keyed open by Dainard followed by Pierpont and Makley the others. Pierpont kicks over the poker table. Escapees throw all the Guards against the wall.

dialogues.speaker: MAKLEY/VAN METER
dialogues.text: (to the Guards) Undress. Get undressed!

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: at the window checks the escape route to the Pontiac. Its clear. Hamilton conceals his weapon and starts out. Smooth. He crosses the front lawn, the street car tracks. So far, so good...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: undress. One takes his time.

dialogues.speaker: SHOUSE
dialogues.text: Hurry up! C'mon! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: This Guard gives Shouse an insolent look. Shouse slams th Guard's head with a length of steel pipe. Guard goes down Shouse goes wild and continues to hammer his skull again again, caving it in.

dialogues.text: Cut it out Shouse!

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: (turns from open door) Shouse!I Dainard thinks that once the killing's begun, he will die So, he grabs for Homer Van Meter's .45. Van Meter SHOOTS Dainard. Dainard's knocked to the floor. Blood pools. A SIREN SCREAMS.

dialogues.text: caught in the open, turns. He scans the guard towers on t East and West corners. He backs towards his Pontiac. RED'S POV: TOWER GUARDS look into the prison interior whe the shots came from.

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: Walter! Dillinger falls away. Dillinger and Pierpont grab Walter' arms. He's-paralyzed now. They try to pull him onto the running boafd, of the moving car. Dietrich's"hcpeful eyes look up at them. Then his eyes gl over. His feet drag down the street. He's dead and they k it. They let go.

dialogues.speaker: DILLIN GER' S
dialogues.text: Thompson empty, he grabs Red's shotgun. He shoves it into Shouse's chest in the backseat.

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: Walter's dead 'cause you screwed it up, you son of a bitch!

dialogues.speaker: SHOUSE
dialogues.text: The bastard wouldn't do what he was told, Johnny. .Pete? Homer? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: Let him have it.

dialogues.speaker: PIERPONT
dialogues.text: Dietrich was your pal, up to you. Dillinger sees the abject fear in Shouse's eyes. And Dillinger's mood swings. He lowers the shotgun... Then, h snaps the butt across Shouse's face. Breaks Shouse's cheekbone. Dillinger pulls back and slams the heavy butt center, smashing Shouse's nose and orbital socket. Dillin opens the door and kicks Shouse out of the moving car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: bounces and rolls across the road into a field. The Ponti races away into the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Dust Bowl America. 1933. Lunar landscape. CAMERA MOV ACROSS brown dunes that half cover farm machinery and a w blasted house. And LANDS ON... JOHN DILLINGER in shirt sleeves and, a vest watchingthe r for pursuit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: change into double breasted suits and shovel down hot cer at a kitchen table. They're in a rush. There is no ;Г‚ВЈy A busted-out farmer, EDWIN NORRIS, hurriedly pours coffee from a kettle into tin mugs and a thermos. A WOMAN at a s fries eggs.

dialogues.speaker: PIERPONT
dialogues.text: (ready to go) okay...?

dialogues.text: wearing a torn smock approaches the Pontiac and a second a dust-covered Plymouth parked behind it.

dialogues.text: (from the house) Johnny...? Ready.

dialogues.speaker: THE WOMAN
dialogues.text: brings out the dozen fried egg sandwiches wrapped in newspaper. She looks 40 but is 20. Edwin Norris is at the door.

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: (takes two) Thank you, ma'am. Dillinger's lopsided smile is charming.

dialogues.speaker: EDWIN NORRIS
dialogues.text: Its Miss. She's my daughter, Viola. That'll be eight dollars. Viola retrieves her toddler brother who's crawled into th Pontiac. Dellinger peels off a $20 bill.

dialogues.speaker: EDWIN NORRIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Can't change that...

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: Well, then you keep the change. $12 is a lot'--'of money in 1933. Grateful, Norris goes i Dillinger passes Viola and the struggling toddler on the to the Pontiac,

dialogues.speaker: VIOLA
dialogues.text: (LOW)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take me with you, mister. She puts a hand on his forearm.

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, honey. Pierpont, Homer and Makley head towards the Plymouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as the Pontiac pulls away, looks back to see Viola wistfu watching them leave. The toddler reaches for Viola's hand She pushes the child away. Dellinger hates seeing the kid rejected.

dialogues.speaker: HAMILTON
dialogues.text: Kid didn't fool with anything, did he? Dillinger, looking back at the boy, hasn't heard. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HAMILTON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Johnnie? All there? Dillinger lifts the coats on the backseat: their weapons as they were.

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: Its all here. (UPBEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go make some money. The speeding cars throw up tails of dust as they drive we to Chicago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: moves quickly through the woods. They run downhill. He we expensive hunting clothes. He carries an 8mm Mauser sport rifle with a slim forestock and wrist and a turned-down b handle. It's the best rifle made in 1933.

dialogues.speaker: HE IS MELVIN PURVIS, (30)
dialogues.text: cleancut and handsome. A square jaw. Chester Gould modell Dick Tracy's profile after Purvis. Has not big, but he's tenacious. He's an incarnation of the social elite of h.i time: white, Southern patrician and a Christian gentleman With Purvis are Special Agents WARREN BARTON (31) and Purvis's friend CARTER DAUM (29) They have a harder time in the steep woods. They're chasi someone. They are guided by East Liverpool police chief, FULTZ.

dialogues.speaker: BOTTOM OF THE HILL
dialogues.text: is a big-boned country boy. His blue suit is mud-streaked from his slide down the hill. He carries a Thompson submachine-gun with a drum magazine, and he is running fo his life.

dialogues.speaker: PURV I S , FULTZ, BAUM
dialogues.text: race after him.

dialogues.speaker: MUDDY PATH
dialogues.text: half runs, half slips in his dress shoes. Ahead is a clea orchard. Floyd leaps the fence... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WOODS
dialogues.text: jumping over fallen trees...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: of apple trees. Floyd's three hundred yards ahead. He zig for a deeper forest at the far end. If he can reach it, h has a chance.

dialogues.speaker: PURVIS
dialogues.text: breaks into the clear.

dialogues.speaker: PURVIS
dialogues.text: Floyd! Halt! Purvis aims the Mauser. Perfect form. Floyd zigzags. Purv FIRES, misses. Floyd opens up with the Thompson -- wildly that range. A few .45s splinter nearby branches. Fultz, Baum and Bart seek cover: Purvis works the bolt and chambers another ro Floyd is 10 yards from the forest. Purvis kneels onto his right knee. On his upraised left k he braces hi left elbow. He inhales. Starts a smooth squeeze. Ha Tway through the exhale he FIRES. Floyd's rig arm flies up. He's punched forward and crashes to the gro

dialogues.speaker: FLOYD
dialogues.text: regains consciousness. Purvis is running in. Floyd`s left hand pulls a 45.

dialogues.speaker: BAUM
dialogues.text: Look out, Melvin! Purvis kicks the 45 out of his hand.

dialogues.speaker: PURVIS
dialogues.text: You are under arrest. Floyd sits up to see the massive exit wound. His right lu and liver are shot through. He falls back.

dialogues.speaker: FLOYD
dialogues.text: (RASPS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Floyd. Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: PURVIS
dialogues.text: Melvin Purvis - Department of Investigation. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PURVIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's your friend Harry Campbell, Floyd?

dialogues.speaker: FLOYD
dialogues.text: Ain't gonna tell you shit. Floyd looks at the sky.

dialogues.speaker: FLOYD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And I believe you have killed me. So you can go and rot in hell, you sonofabitch. He lapses, goes cold and dies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAROLE SLAYMAN is 33 with green eyes and peroxide blonde and bounces down the stairs in a black robe. She crosses through a white kitchen with TWO GIRLS in kimonos. A scar African-American bouncer of 50 named SPORT enters...

dialogues.speaker: SPORT
dialogues.text: He jus' pulled in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: sees Dillinger's Pontiac stop in the backyard. It's`-secl by a hedge from the street. Its followed by the Plymouth with Pierpont and Van Meter in suits and prison haircuts.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLE
dialogues.text: Johnny! Dillinger cradles the Thompson in his arm and crosses to

dialogues.text: (to Hamilton) Hey, Red, call Oscar.

dialogues.text: Okay. And Berman? Wanna switch-out the "shorts"?

dialogues.text: (ADDS)

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Carole) You get a hold of Zarkovich...?

dialogues.speaker: CAROLE
dialogues.text: I sure did... (LAUGHING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put me down!

dialogues.speaker: JAN METER
dialogues.text: Where those gals?! As Homer and Pierpont head inside...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OSCAR`s a 50 year old German gunsmith. Dillinger rapidly field strips his Thompson.

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: (re main spring) Jammed twice, Oscar., .main spring's too tight.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: cut off one coil.

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: And it rides up and to the right on full auto.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: (re Cutts compensator) I widen port...

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY.
dialogues.text: Dillinger rises as a 1933 Chrysler and an Essex Terraplane drive in. Out of the Essex steps HARRY BERMAN, a Cicero, Illinois auto dealer for the Syndicate. (Berman will swit out the Dillinger Gang's work cars or "shorts.")

dialogues.speaker: PIERPONT
dialogues.text: Hiya Harry...

dialogues.speaker: PIERPONT
dialogues.text: tosses Berman a rubber banded roll of bills while...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: enters. MARTIN ZARKOVICH looks up. He wears a police badg and a 38 in a shoulder holster. He is a corrupt detective the East Chicago, Indiana Police Department.

dialogues.speaker: ZARKOVIOH
dialogues.text: Johnny! How are ya? With him is ANNA SAGE, a 40 year old well-dressed madam. kisses Johnny on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: Good and so are you. Christmas is coming early this year. (fat envelope of cash) Extra cake's in here for you and Anna. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still in Hammond, doll?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA SAGE
dialogues.text: I'm in Chicago on North Halstead now. Come on by...

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: Marty, tell me that me and my boys are okay...

dialogues.speaker: ZARKOVICH
dialogues.text: Long as you stay in my town, you're in safe haven. Dillinger tosses Marty the envelope. This is Dillinger's support and resupply network.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: in a deep armchair with his shoes off and his feet on a hassock. Paul Whiteman's Big Band is on the console radio Carole slides onto his lap and snuggles into his shoulder John glows with the affection.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLE
dialogues.text: Wanna go out later, sugar?

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: I want to sit here with you and listen to the radio, baby. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have missed you like nobody's business... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: John Dillinger seems like a romantic husband with his lit wife Betty. And it feels a little out of place...

dialogues.speaker: MCKELLAR
dialogues.text: (to Hoover) Why do we need this?

dialogues.speaker: HOOVER
dialogues.text: Because of the new breed of mobile outlaws who flee jurisdiction by crossing state lines over highways and against whom this government must wage a war on crime. J. EDGAR HOOVER is a physically short man but has a dynam presence. He is a dapper patrician who believes in elites is completely free from self-doubt. He is youthful and 33 years old. SUYDAM and TOLSON sit next to him. MCKELLAR iГЇВїВЅ'Chairman of the Senate Appropriations Su Committee.-,He's an avuncular man of 62.

dialogues.speaker: MCKELLAR
dialogues.text: And so in the middle of a Great Depression you're looking for a budget increase to build up your Department? But by my tally your Department of Investigation spends more taxpayer's dollars catching crooks than what the crooks you catch stole in the first place...

dialogues.speaker: HOOVER
dialogues.text: That's ridiculous. The Bureau's apprehended kidnappers, bank robbers, who have stolen up to...

dialogues.speaker: MCKELLAR
dialogues.text: (looking at document) How many criminals you apprehended?

dialogues.speaker: HOOVER
dialogues.text: We've arrested and arraigned 213 wanted felons...

dialogues.speaker: MCKELLAR
dialogues.text: No. I mean you. How many? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HOOVER
dialogues.text: As Director I've administered...

dialogues.speaker: MCKELLAR
dialogues.text: No. How many have you arrested? Personally.

dialogues.speaker: HOOVER
dialogues.text: I've never arrested anybody.

dialogues.speaker: MCKELLAR
dialogues.text: (INCREDULOUS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You never arrested anybody?

dialogues.speaker: HOOVER
dialogues.text: I'm an administrator.

dialogues.speaker: MCKELLAR
dialogues.text: With no field experience. For once Hoover is silent.

dialogues.speaker: MCKELLAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (CONTINUING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In fact you are shockingly unqualified, aren't you, sir? You have never personally conducted a criminal investigation in the field in your life= Others in the room stare at Hoover. McKellar leans'-back.

dialogues.speaker: MCKELLAR
dialogues.text: (CONTINUING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you are a front. I think your prowess as a lawman is a myth created from a hoopla of headlines by Mr. Suydam, your publicist there. You are trying to make a federal police force with you set up as its Czar. That is runnin' wild in my estimation...

dialogues.speaker: HOOVER
dialogues.text: Crime is what runs wild in this country, Mr. Chairman. And...

dialogues.speaker: MCKELLAR
dialogues.text: And if the country required an expanded Bureau, I question you are the person most fit to run it while... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HOOVER
dialogues.text: (EXPLODES)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't be judged by a kangaroo court of venal politicians...

dialogues.speaker: MCKELLAR
dialogues.text: (slams gavel!) While outlaws like Dillinger, Clyde Barrow, the Barkers, and Nelson flourish unabated. (SLAM)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your appropriation request is denied. The hearing's over.

dialogues.speaker: TNT. U.S. CONGRESS, CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: walks fast through the corridor of congressmen. He talks his left shoulder to Suydam and Tolson. They struggle to him...

dialogues.speaker: HOOVER
dialogues.text: (to Suydam) Find out: was he soft on the Reds in ,1919? Does he use prostitutes? Peppy `tuf f like that. And feed this to Walter =!riiГўВЂВћinchell: "McKellar's a Neanderthal. He's O7:a personal vendetta to destroy me." Like that. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll fight him on the front page. Not in his damn committee room... (to Tolson) Where's Dillinger?

dialogues.speaker: TOLSON
dialogues.text: Spotted in Hammond, Indiana.

dialogues.speaker: HOOVER
dialogues.text: How long ago?

dialogues.speaker: TOLSON
dialogues.text: Yesterday. Another sighting has him on the Lincoln Highway in Ohio heading towards Cincinnati.

dialogues.speaker: HOOVER
dialogues.text: (DECIDES)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's in Hammond. Heading to Chicago.

dialogues.speaker: SUYDAM
dialogues.text: How do you know? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HOOVER
dialogues.text: You can have fun in Chicago. What the hell's there to do in Cincinnati?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: enters. Melvin Purvis has been waiting. He's gestured to follow.

dialogues.speaker: HOOVER
dialogues.text: (suddenly brilliant) Agent Purvis, congratulations.

dialogues.speaker: PURVIS
dialogues.text: Thank you sir. May I ask why?

dialogues.speaker: HOOVER
dialogues.text: Pretty Boy Floyd, for which you have my commendation and personal gratitude. Second, you are, as of this moment, the Special Agent in Charge of the Chicago field office. Your task will be to get John Dillinger. Are you up to it?

dialogues.speaker: PURVIS
dialogues.text: Absolutely, sir. Purvis is imbued. Henry Suydam enters.

dialogues.speaker: SUYDAM
dialogues.text: (to Hoover) They're ready for him.

dialogues.speaker: HOOVER
dialogues.text: (PENSIVE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Henry Suydam.. He is our expert in congressional and press relations. INT. BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION w HOOVER ESCORTS PURVIS THRO

dialogues.speaker: THE OPEN PLAN OFFICE
dialogues.text: Tolson + Suydam follow. It's like the "Corporate Office of the Future" designed b Albrecht Speer. Agents are at grey metal desks dressed identically in dark suits, white shirts, dark ties. No personal effects. The individual is reduced to a componen a gleaming machine.

dialogues.speaker: TOLSON
dialogues.text: hurry down the staircase. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HOOVER
dialogues.text: (LOW)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you sure you're up to this task, Mr. Purvis?

dialogues.speaker: PURVIS
dialogues.text: We have two weapons that cannot be defeated.

dialogues.speaker: HOOVER
dialogues.text: What are they?

dialogues.speaker: PURVIS
dialogues.text: The Bureau's modern techniques of investigation and your visionary leadership.

dialogues.speaker: HOOVER
dialogues.text: You let Mr. Tolson, here, know if you need anything, Melvin, anything at all,

dialogues.speaker: PURVIS
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: HOOVER
dialogues.text: (brilliant smile) Call me J.E. They shake hands. There's a mob of photographers and news and microphones to interview him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: is awed. He's imbued with purpose. He's been anointed Hoover's Crimebuster. He claimed he was up to the task. "Is he?" he asks himself right now. And he didn't expect be overcome by doubt. He struggles with anxiety. Then, he pushes that aside and forces himself to take the step for into the lights and flashbulbs.

dialogues.speaker: SUYDAM
dialogues.text: (quietly to Tolson) Our own Clark Gable...

dialogues.text: in a long overcoat and a hat with a Tommy gun crosses a b interior to a thin man behind a large desk, GROVER WEYLA_ (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: Grover stands and flattens against the back wall, as if trying to permeate the masonry and disappear into the bac alley. Dillinger peels him off the wall and steers him towards t vault.

dialogues.text: Let's play a game, Mr. President. Its called spin the dial. (starts stopwatch, shouts to

dialogues.text: is the Lobby Man. His back is to the front door. He contr the customers on the inside. Women are seated on the floo Men stand. It's well-ordered. Pete doesn't worry about hi back because...

dialogues.text: is the Lookout. His back is to the front door. His,job is control the people outside the bank. His 351 Winchester rifle is hidden by his coat. Crowds gather across th' str because of the alarm. Homer's focused. He is rock steady.

dialogues.text: is at the tellers' drawers. His job is to shovel cash int canvas bag. The Tellers stand aside.

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: at the vault with Weyland. Weyland hesitates. Dillinger's right hand with the Thompson covers Tellers so Makley can work. His left hand draws one of the two 45s he keeps in twin shoulder holsters and he cracks Grover Weyland acros the forehead. He aims the .45 between Weyland's eyes...

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: (CALM)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can be a dead hero or a live coward. Grover Weyland OPENS THE VAULT. Dillinger checks his watc

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: spots a police car racing up, TAPS the window with the ba of his rifle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: glances outside.

dialogues.speaker: PIERPONT
dialogues.text: (CALMLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Company! NO ONE inside stops working. They know Van Meter will do job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: is out of the car and into the bank door, passing right b

dialogues.speaker: VAN METER
dialogues.text: -- who let him go. Van Meter keeps his eye on the other T COPS. Two get behind the cover of parked cars across the street. ONE stays low and runs towards Homer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: marches into the lobby, gun in hand.

dialogues.speaker: BOYARD
dialogues.text: (CONFIDENTLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold it! Hands up! PIERPONT, behind him, slams the butt of the Thompson into back of his head, knocking him flat, and disarms him. He rouses. Pete doesn't like authority. Pete hits him again. Blood pools onto the floor. A WOMAN faints, collapsing. Peters dead calm. He looks ov the half-painted windows. The growing crowd on the sidewa is getting too large...

dialogues.speaker: HE FIRES
dialogues.text: at the glass. People scramble for cover as it CRASHES ont Main Street. Meanwhile...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: engine idling, sees people running past. Taped to his das are two "Г‚В°gits" - step by step instructions to two getaway routes. He checks his watch. The minute hand moves into place. He drives evenly out of the alley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: is approached by the COP who thinks he's a pedestrian. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: (to Homer) Hey, you. Move out of there!

dialogues.speaker: VAN METER
dialogues.text: Why should I? I wanna watch. Angry Cop rushes him. Homer slams him in the gut with his rifle, disarms him and uses him as a shield. He backs to front door. Pedestrians flee. Cops draw down. They cannot shoot without Homer blowing off the Cop's head. Meanwhile

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: tosses the last bag to Pierpont at the front door. On. th out he passes a FARMER near a teller's cage, his hands in air. Cash on the counter.

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: That your money there, mister?

dialogues.speaker: FARMER
dialogues.text: Yessir. It is.

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: Well, go ahead and put it away. We're here for the bank's money. Not your money. Customers appreciate Dillinger. Dillinger loves their- appreciation...

dialogues.speaker: PIERPONT
dialogues.text: You three! Let's go! .to three pretty TELLERS hiding under a desk.

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: Folks, stay calm and stay low. Pierpont grabs two; Dillinger takes one, creating a human shield around them --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: his gun against the side of the cop's head, moves to the Buick. A large crowd is across the street.

dialogues.speaker: CITY DETECTIVES
dialogues.text: pull up in front of Wylie's Hat shop. Dillinger's crew is crossing fast to Red's Buick, as... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER OPENS UP
dialogues.text: and the Wylie Hat Shop windows blow out. A DETECTIVE with a deer rifle aims.

dialogues.speaker: VAN METER
dialogues.text: FIRES past his hostage's head. Detective goes down. The Hostage's eardrum is blown. His ear bleeds. DILLINGER SHOOTS UP... City Detectives' car, police car and a few others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: are in. Dillinger and hostages load onto the running boar Pierpont grabs ANNA PATZKE's arm.

dialogues.speaker: PIERPONT
dialogues.text: C'mere, honey. Buick's moving faster. Dillinger pulls her onto the runni board next--:o Boyard. The Buick roars away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: drives with total concentration. Makley cooly reads the g

dialogues.speaker: MAKLEY
dialogues.text: 2 miles - turn left at the white barn. Right there. Now. 6 miles to the new bridge. Pierpont breaks out the rear window. He throws two five gallon milk jars full of roofing nails out into the road. They scatter.

dialogues.speaker: TWO POLICE CARS
dialogues.text: hit the nails, their tires blow. ROUNDS from the Buick fi dissuading them to pursue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: approaches the bridge, slows.

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: (to Boyard and two of the

dialogues.speaker: HOSTAGES
dialogues.text: Okay. Beat it! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Three hostages jump off. Dillinger pulls Anna Patzke and Weyland inside.

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: sees Anna Patzke's shivering from shock and the cold. He his coat on her. He plops his hat on her head, too.

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Something to remember me by. She laughs, nervously, and a little thrilled at being whe she is...

dialogues.speaker: VAN METER
dialogues.text: (OMINOUS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are we taking `em to the hideout?

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: (going along with it That depends.

dialogues.speaker: VAN METER
dialogues.text: How 'bout it, honey? Can you cook?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA PATZKE
dialogues.text: (not disinterested) Uh. Sure... After a fashion. They start to hoot and laugh. They think this is hГ‚В±l i

dialogues.speaker: ANNA PATZKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well, its true!

dialogues.speaker: VAN METER
dialogues.text: When I'm not doing this, I'm a scout for the movies.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA PATZKE
dialogues.text: Really? This makes them laugh even harder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pierpont has brought the hostages to a big tree.

dialogues.speaker: PIERPONT
dialogues.text: Face each other. Join hands. Pierpont binds them loosely to the tree. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WEYLAND
dialogues.text: We'll freeze.

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: You'll worm your way out of that in about ten minutes. Anna looks over at Dellinger.

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It's okay, doll. You're just gonna be a little late for dinner. Dillinger reaches over, snatches his hat off Anna Patzke' head. He leaves her his coat.

dialogues.speaker: THE BUICK WORK CAR
dialogues.text: is abandoned.

dialogues.speaker: TRACK RIGHT
dialogues.text: Dillinger''b Essex and a Ford drive off past fields with on both sides. New cars. Flush with cash. Clean.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. CHICAGt7: BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION OFFICES - PURVIS - (BANKER' S BUILDING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: looks at the gathered agents. New faces. College men.

dialogues.speaker: WARREN BARTON
dialogues.text: holds up the coat Dillinger left on Anna Patzke.

dialogues.speaker: BAUM
dialogues.text: .manufactured by Freeman & Freeman in St. Louis. We are identifying all stores that sold this coat. We note AGENTS COWLEY, RICE, CLEGG + RORER. DORIS ROGERS is Purvis' secretary. He brought her from his last post i Alabama along with Barton and Baum. We've entered mid-sce

dialogues.speaker: PURVIS
dialogues.text: Then we will cross-reference every Dillinger family member and known associate in each locale. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was there. It got cold. He bought a coat. Therefore, he may have been harbored or have a safe house nearby. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PURVIS
dialogues.text: By such techniques we will get Dillinger. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doris... (STOPS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For those of you who haven't met her, Miss Rogers is my secretary... (to Doris) Please contact the Chicago telephone exchange supervisors. Request appointments for Carter Baum or myself. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are going to be working long hours. It will be dangerous. Those of you who aren't prepared for that, can go. And if you're going to go, go now. (no one does) Thank you, gentlemen.

dialogues.speaker: E/I. ARAGON BALLROOM, CHICAGO
dialogues.text: watching a sexy young woman on the dance floor. He loses sight of her... He's expecting someone. Then, Dillinger sees her again: j black hair in a bob, brown eyes, high cheekbones fom:her Indian mother and a great smile. She lights up a ro om. S BILLIE FRECHETTE (27). She feels the stare and looks over. She studies him, then looks away. Dillinger's with Pierpont, Makley and Hamilton at a table is loaded with steaks, oysters, and frog legs. ALVIN KARPIS and Homer Van Meter approach and Alvin sits to Johnnie... Dillinger adjusts his chair to watch for th girl. He's shoulder to shoulder to Karpis.

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: Hiya, Alvin. You hungry? How's Freddie and Dock? (note: Alvin Karpis is cunning and careful. He will outli everyone, including J. Edgar Hoover, and retire to Torremolinos, Spain, where he will die of heart failure i 1979. Freddie and Dock Barker are the sons of Ma Barker. After FBI gunned down the old woman, Hoover labeled her the "cr genius" of the family. According to Volney Davis, she couldn't organize breakfast.) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: KARPIS
dialogues.text: Everyone's good. (leans in; they talk quietly) We been looking to snatch two fellas. One's a St. Paul banker, Ed Bremer. Need a few more hands.

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: Don't like kidnapping.

dialogues.speaker: KARPIS
dialogues.text: Robbing banks is getting tougher.

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: The public don't like kidnappers.

dialogues.speaker: KARPIS
dialogues.text: Who gives a damn what the public likes?

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: I do. I hide out among them.

dialogues.speaker: KARPIS
dialogues.text: (SHRUGS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ,L -am strictly out to make cake.

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: .: yeah, then you, Ma, Dock and Freddie hole up like hermits on farms for six months. I grew up on a goddamn farm. I hate farms. I like big cities, crowds and a good time...

dialogues.speaker: K ARP IS
dialogues.text: (SMILES)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we got a mail train we been lookin' at, too.

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: Say, by the way, if someone got pinched here, who can get'em out real fast?

dialogues.speaker: KARPIS
dialogues.text: Lawyer named Piquett. We all use him. (writes a phone number)

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: What about this train?..

dialogues.speaker: KARPIS
dialogues.text: Needs two, three more months to set up. I need seven or eight real right guys to take it down. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: (SMILES)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds like Jesse James.

dialogues.speaker: KARPIS
dialogues.text: (LOW)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A million seven, a million eight. Dillinger looks at Karpis. In 2007, that would be $22 million.

dialogues.speaker: KARPIS, (CONT' D)
dialogues.text: Federal Reserve shipment. It runs only twice a month. This is the kind of score you go away on after.

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: Where you gonna go?

dialogues.speaker: KARPIS
dialogues.text: Brazil. Cuba, maybe. What about you?

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: Were having too good a time today. We ain't worryin' about tomorrow yet...

dialogues.speaker: KARPIS
dialogues.text: You ought to. What we're doin' here, don't last forever. They lock at each other: two pros at the top of their gam

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: Keep me in mind on the train. Karpis leaves. Dellinger can't see Billie anymore.

dialogues.speaker: JA' METER
dialogues.text: (AGITATED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's snatch Bremer... (LOUDER)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Know how much they made snatchin' that Hamm Brewery guy? $250,000. Dillinger looks at Pierpont.

dialogues.speaker: P IERPONT
dialogues.text: Shut your yap, Homer.

dialogues.speaker: MAKLEY
dialogues.text: Let's get our of here. Pierpont, Homer and Makley leave. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: Homer stayin' steady?

dialogues.speaker: HAMILTON
dialogues.text: (reading his mind) He's okay.

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: Three rules I learned from Walter Dietrich. One: never work with people who are desperate. Two: never work with people who aren't the best. Three: never work when you're not ready. Billie reappears, dancing with a young man.

dialogues.speaker: HAMILTON
dialogues.text: Well, I got rule four: stay away from women.

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: Without women, I might as well have `stayed in stir. Anna Sage approaches with a young girl for Red.

dialogues.speaker: HAMILTON
dialogues.text: What's why they invented whores. (getting up) Hamilton leaves, arms around the women. Dillinger keeps h eye on Billie. Music ends. Young man escorts her to her table. He tries to join her. She turns him down. Dillinger finishes his drink, approaches. He now sees how beautiful Billie is. She's 5 foot 5. With a straight erec build, she stands out in any crowd. She looks Dillinger straight in the eye. Clear skin, dark eyes with humor pla about the edges. He unexpectedly starts to feel nervous. He gives her his best grin.

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: I don't know what you said to your friend, but I sure am glad you did. Billie looks him over: a well-made man in a good suit wit great smile. And, paradoxes: he easily talks to women but he's not a hustler. He's young, but there's a world of experience in his face. Open, but he's holding something back. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: Billie Frechette.

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: Buy you a drink? Billie looks at her girlfriend, she nods, Billie rises... As they cross to the bar.

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER, (CONT'B)
dialogues.text: Is that French?

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: On my father's side. There's an "e" at the end. Do you have a name?

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: Jack Harris. Music changes to "Bye Bye Blackbird."

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: Do you dance, Jack?

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: I don't know how. She smiles a pretty smile at him.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: How come you don't know how to dance? Its easy. Follow me. This is a two-step. (he stares at her feet) Don't look at my feet. Look at my shoulders. She stays an inch or two distant in his arms. Its slow an languorous. He follows her with little difficulty. He can smell the perfume in her black hair.

dialogues.speaker: TORCH SINGER
dialogues.text: (SINGS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ГўВЂВћPack-up all my cares and woe Here I go, singing low Bye, bye blackbird"

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: My, but you are pretty. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: They look into each other's eyes. He pulls her closer, wa to kiss her long smooth neck. He almost can't resist... Their lips are an inch apart. And then she rests her chee his shoulder and the kiss that wasn't hangs in the air ar them. He whispers...

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER., (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Where you from, Billie? She turns her right ear towards him. She's deaf in her le ear.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: Flandreau.

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: Where's Flandreau.?

dialogues.speaker: TORCH SINGER
dialogues.text: (SINGS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Where somebody waits for me Sugar's sweet, so is she Bye, bye blackbird..."

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: outh Dakota.

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: Father's French, what's on the other side?

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: Italian.

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: From South Dakota, Indian's likelier than Italian. She looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: My momma's a Menominee Indian. But most men don't like that...

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: I'm not most men.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: And I check coats at the Steuben Club. What do you do, Jack?

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: I'm catching up. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: Catching up on what?

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: On life, meeting someone like you. (her hair) Dark, beautiful, like the black bird in that song... She laughs at the flattery. Holds his eyes a beat with an ironic look. A couple from another group looks at Dilling He's cool. He returns the look. They look away.

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: Say, how'd you like some dinner?

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: Sure. He nods courteously to her girlfriends, grabs her coat, p a hand around Billie's waist and steers her out...

dialogues.speaker: TORCH SINGER
dialogues.text: (SINGS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "So make my bed and light the light Cause I'll be home late tonight Bye, bye blackbird... ."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: in their coats on the street. It's cold. Dillinger.pulls close. Then he turns and he kisses her hard on the lips. She did expect that. Her eyes are wide. He opens and wraps her in overcoat, their bodies close to each other. She kisses him back, long and deep. And she didn't expect do that, either. At last they separate.. .and look at each other for a bea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dillinger slips him bills. He and Billie are shown to a table. The clientele is North Shore old money and businessmen. Some of the women are in dazzling dresses ev though it's mid-Depression. A few stare at Billie. She's of her class.

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: What are you gonna have? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Billie stares at him, ignoring her menu.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: What is it, exactly, you do for a living? Dillinger looks over the top of his menu.

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: Well...I rob banks. Then he leans back in his chair and regards her.

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That's where all these people here put their money.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: Why'd you tell me that? You could have made up a story...

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: 'Cause I can't lie to you. she studies him carefully.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: ;,;.at's a pretty serious thing to say to a woman you just met.

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: I feel like I know you.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: Well, I haven't been any of the places you've been. So I don't even know what I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: Some of the places I been ain't so hot. Where I'm going is a lot better. Wanna come along?

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: Boy, you are in a hurry.

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: If you were looking at what I am looking at, honey, you'd be in a hurry too. She laughs at his flattery, which she is also finding persuasive. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: (leans in) Well, its me they're looking at this time.

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: That's 'cause you're beautiful. A blonde woman, elegant and ice cold, stares at Billie, a Depression-era child in her dress.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: That's nice. But they're looking at me because they're not used to having a Menominee Indian girl in their restaurant in a three dollar dress.

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: (takes her hand) Listen, doll, that's 'cause they're all about where people come from. Only thing important is where somebody's going.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: To the top. He's irresistible.

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER, (COIN' D)
dialogues.text: Let's get out of here. Beat. She nods. They get up, get their things. On their way...a man intercepts Dillinger. He is GILBERT CATENA (42), solid with big hands. He's smiling.

dialogues.speaker: CATENA
dialogues.text: (WHISPERED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Johnny...: Dillinger reacts, changes down, says coldly...

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: (to Billie) Go wait outside. I'll be right there. Billie turns and walks out of the restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How you been, Gil? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CATENA
dialogues.text: Real good. I work for Mr. Nitti now. Been with him since I got out of Michigan... Catena indicates FRANK NITTI (47) in a group at a table. Sober and educated, Nitti glances in their direction but no interest.

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: Looks like a barber.

dialogues.speaker: CATENA
dialogues.text: Don't go by looks. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's real smart. We're connected to everybody all over the country now... From Nitti's table a man gets up and walks straight towar Dillinger. He is PHIL D'ANDREA. Two heavy duty bodyguards with him. Dillinger unbuttons his jacket. But...

dialogues.speaker: D'ANDREA
dialogues.text: (smiles, low) Everytime I read about one of your jobs, where you give people back their money, 'You crack me up... (LAUGHS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ypu need anything, Gilbert knows how to find me. D'Andrea continues to the men's room.

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: See you. Gilbert...

dialogues.speaker: CATENA
dialogues.text: Good luck Johnnie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: comes out onto the sidewalk. Billie isn't there. He searc the street. She's gone. The night, suddenly cold and lone wraps around Johnny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An ENGINEER places headphones on Purvis' ears. Acetate di on turntables mounted within giant carrying cases record phone calls. Cloth insulated wires are strung everywhere. Stenographers sit with black bakelite headphones. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BAUM
dialogues.text: That noise on the line? That's called "swing". Nothing we can do about it. Some words get dropped. Were listening in on a car dealer. Harry Berman. Rice plays back a recording.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: When you drop it, leave the keys on the floorboard. (muffled; then...)

dialogues.speaker: B E RMAN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I got a DeSoto.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: okay.

dialogues.speaker: BERMAN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: The interior's no good.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Don't matter. It's a work. car.

dialogues.speaker: BAUM
dialogues.text: We think that's Dillinger's voice.

dialogues.speaker: PURVIS
dialogues.text: How did we find Berman?

dialogues.speaker: BAUM
dialogues.text: Dillinger's coat was bought in Cicero, Illinois, a few doors from Berman's dealership. Berman supplies cars to the syndicate. Since Capone. Dillinger must have been at Berman's switching cars when he bought that coat. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soon as they call to switch out the next car, we will tail them. Right to Dillinger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: gets out of his Buick...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: enters, sees Billie talking with another hostess, MAY MINCZELES. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: TWO MEN approach. Billie checks their hats and coats. To Dillinger...

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: (without looking up) May I check your coat, sir?

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: No, honey. You go get your coat. She looks up. So does May. May flashes Billie a look: if don't want him, I do.

dialogues.speaker: MAY MINCZELES
dialogues.text: Sounds good to me. Dillinger has eyes only for Billie.

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: You ran out on me.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: `you left me standing alone on the sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: I 'you're going to be my girl, you have swear you'll never do that again.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: I'm not your girl! A CUSTOMER comes up and puts his ticket on the counter.

dialogues.speaker: CUSTOMER
dialogues.text: Brown overcoat.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: (ignoring customer) I am not your girl and I'm not going to say that.

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: I'm waiting.

dialogues.speaker: CUSTOMER
dialogues.text: So am I. DILLINGER. (to Billie) "I am not ever going to run out on you again." Say it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: Well, I will never run out on you. And that's a promise.

dialogues.speaker: CUSTOMER
dialogues.text: Well, I want to run out of here. So, lady, will you get my coat...? Dillinger lifts the man two feet off the floor and slams into the wall. Real jailhouse rage. The lethally cold eye tells the customer everything he needs to know. Dillinger swings him to the counter, grabs the man's ticket, slams the half door, finds the man's coat, tosses it at him...

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: Keep the tip. (to Billie) You ain't getting other people's hats and coats no more either. He takes her coat and holds it for her. She doesn't move.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: No one's ever done that for me before.

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: You're with me now.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: I don't know anything about you.

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: I was raised on a farm in Mooresville, Indiana. My ma died when I was three. My daddy beat the hell out of me because he didn't know no better way to raise me. I used to do dumb things but I'm a lot smarter now. I like baseball, movies, good clothes, fast cars, and you. What else do you need to know? She gets into her coat. Dillinger opens the door for her. They exit, watched by May.

dialogues.speaker: TNT. DILLINGER'S APARTMENT, LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: enters. It's large, low-ceilinged, luxurious and modern - Billie is bowled over. He sits her down on a sofa. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He goes into a closet to get two Marshall Fields boxes an two drinks.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: You been living here long?

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: Yeah. Since yesterday. From a back bedroom (Red's) a phonograph is louder as a d opens and Red enters the kitchen in a robe for a drink. H returns. Laughter. Dillinger has the boxes and drinks.

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I got something for you. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong? Open it up. Billie opens the boxes. She lifts out a sleeveless dress dusty pink. It is beautiful. She is very touched. The sec has a coat with a fur color. But still...

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: I'm drinking in a man's apartment who .:W.ants to romance me. Okay. I'm no "Pollyanna, but there are things that you Kati would bother a girl like me...

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: We`rob banks `cause banks is where they keep the money. I can make 500 dollars in a year or I can make ten thousand dollars in a morning. I'll take my chances on the bank. No apologies. We don't go lookin' to hurt anybody. But if somebody gets in our way, that's gotta be their problem. That what you want to know?

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: I'm trying to get to know you.

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: You want to get to know me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dillinger is an uninhibited and enthusiastic lover. They pause. He falls over onto his back and pulls her onto his chest they look up out the window through the upside down elm t to the Chicago moon in the cold sky. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She gets up and wanders around the room. He thinks she's most beautiful creature he's ever seen. She's looking at stuff. She sees suitcases that are packed, ready to leave in a heartbeat. Everything's so neat. She touches his folded shirt...

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: .smooth

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: Egyptian cotton. Since we been out I go for the finest stuff. As much as I can get, as fast we can get it.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: (SUITCASES)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where you goin'?

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: Nowhere. What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: You're all packed.

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: Always are. Ready to get up and go in a heartbeat... She stands next to him in the bed now. He pulls her down to him.. She turns her good ear towards him.

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What's wrong with the other ear?

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: I was married once. He was too handy with his fists. She stares at Dillinger. Will this put him off.

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: Where's he now?

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: In prison. I divorced him. Only mistake I made was marrying him in the first place. He got caught mugging a mailman...

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: A criminal mastermind... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She turns over and puts her mouth next to his ear. It get amorous through...

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: After my daddy died, we went to live on the reservation in Flandreau. In Flandreau nothin' ever happened. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I was 13, we went to live with my Aunt Ines in Milwaukee where my cousin Frances had a lot of Indian friends who went around to churches and put on plays like "Little Fireface." And nothing exciting ever happened to me there, either. So I haven't been anywhere or done anything in my whole life except come to Chicago and try to make my way.

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: Well baby-you're going to start a new and exciting kind of life from right now. And as they're pulled to each other and start making love again, she stops...

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: heat do you want?

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: To please you. That's not what she meant, but gently, he rolls her over the bed. A smile spreads slowly across her lips.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: Baum in his shirtsleeves in front of the recorders is tal to Purvis as he puts on his coat.

dialogues.speaker: BAUM
dialogues.text: Rorer tailed it. Berman dropped it in an alley next to the Sherone Apartments 20 minutes ago. Rorer talked to a neighbor. Men go in and out at night carrying heavy suitcases. One looks like Dillinger.

dialogues.speaker: PURVIS
dialogues.text: Let's go. Right now. They race out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cowley and Barton join them as they pull to the curb down block from the Sherone Apartments. It's an upscale yellow brick apartment building with nice cars in front.

dialogues.speaker: PURVI S
dialogues.text: Where are your men?

dialogues.speaker: COWLEY
dialogues.text: My car's on Sheridan and Montrose and Rice in the Ford is on Sheridan and Wilson.

dialogues.speaker: PURVIS
dialogues.text: Blocking vehicles? End of this street? Alley? They aren't "deployed." They're merely "here". Cowley get it. Purvis exchanges a look with Baum, checks his gun.

dialogues.speaker: PURVIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Carter, take the back. Barton, you're with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: enter from the elevator. Soundlessly, they approach'-Apt. Two voices - a man and a woman's. Barton moves away,Irom door... Purvis knocks. VI SCOTT (27) opens the door. From ier reaction, she was expecting someone else. She's respectab and pretty.

dialogues.speaker: PURVIS
dialogues.text: I'm Special Agent Melvin Purvis, Miss Scott. Are you alone?

dialogues.speaker: VI SCOTT
dialogues.text: No - my fiance is here.

dialogues.speaker: PURVIS
dialogues.text: What's your fiance's name?

dialogues.speaker: VI SCOTT
dialogues.text: Leonard... McHenry.

dialogues.speaker: PURVIS
dialogues.text: May we come in? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: VI SCOTT
dialogues.text: Sure. I'm perfectly safe... But come on in. She holds the door open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LEONARD is a thin short man at a table finishing dinner. is fresh-faced, maybe a junior clerk at an insurance comp Not John Dillinger...

dialogues.speaker: LEONARD
dialogues.text: Something wrong?

dialogues.speaker: PURVIS
dialogues.text: You have identification?

dialogues.speaker: LEONARD
dialogues.text: Honey, would you get my driver's licence. It's in my coat pocket. Leonard sums reluctant to get up. With his right hand, he takes a forkful of food. His left is under the table. Now see that he:.'s holding...

dialogues.speaker: A COLT 45_.-,AUTOMATIC
dialogues.text: Who is this man?

dialogues.speaker: LEONARD
dialogues.text: You're that.. .Melvin Purvis. I've seen your picture!

dialogues.speaker: PURVIS
dialogues.text: What do you do for a living, Leonard?

dialogues.speaker: LEONARD
dialogues.text: I travel in ladies shoes. He smiles at his joke. Vi enters with his wallet. Barton the driver's license.

dialogues.speaker: LEONARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Show him, honey. Vi Scott puts a foot forward - a red shoe with a bow.

dialogues.speaker: PURVIS
dialogues.text: Do you carry around samples?

dialogues.speaker: LEONARD
dialogues.text: Sure. Big suitcases. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PURVIS
dialogues.text: (handing back the licence) Enjoy the rest of your dinner, Mr. McHenry.

dialogues.speaker: LEONARD
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: walk the length of the hall. Vi closed the door behind th

dialogues.speaker: PURVIS
dialogues.text: (LOW)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Its all wrong. No one in or out. I'll get the others. (at door to stairs next to the elevator door) Stay here, watch that door from right here. Purvis leaves. Barton wants to do it right. Then, he hear movement from Apt. 302. Objects being hurriedly shifted. starts back down the hallway. Halfway between it and the elevator...

dialogues.speaker: PING
dialogues.text: Behind him, the elevator doors open. Barton turns hi.,,ba Apt. 302. He's caught between 302 and the elevator.-".-

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY CARROLL, (38)
dialogues.text: a flat-nosed ex-con enters. He looks curiously at Barton.

dialogues.speaker: BARTON
dialogues.text: Bureau of Investigation. What's your name? (flashes badge)

dialogues.speaker: CARROLL
dialogues.text: You wanna know my name? Barton sees Carroll's eyes flicker, slight smile. He spin

dialogues.speaker: AN INDIFFERENT "BABY FACE" NELSON
dialogues.text: FIRES his .45. BLAM! BLAM! Barton's slammed forward. Nelson looks at Barton, prostra convulsing. He FIRES a third round.

dialogues.speaker: PURVIS
dialogues.text: Pull the men from Sheridan and Wilson.

dialogues.speaker: PURVIS
dialogues.text: -reacting- grabs the Thompson from Madala and runs back inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: runs to the corner of the building where he has a visual the building front entrance and the DeSoto down the alley

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: enters, sees...

dialogues.speaker: BARTON
dialogues.text: in the final moments of his life. Barton looks up into Purvis` eyes: Help me! Purvis does not know what to do. Then Barton's eyes drift away... Purvis impels himself to action. He kicks in the door to 302. ГЇВїВЅ._

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: screams.

dialogues.speaker: PURVIS
dialogues.text: Where is he?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: sees -

dialogues.speaker: BABY FACE NELSON
dialogues.text: quickly cross the alley from the back stairs to the Desot And Nelson immediately lays down rounds in careful short BLASTS of full auto. Tommy Carroll calmly, smoothly start the DeSoto. Nelson's barrage punches into the wall, drive Daum to cover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: slams open a window. The DeSoto accelerates out of the al Purvis FIRES a few rounds. Baum FIRES his pistol. Both ar useless at that range. The DeSoto has turned left and is gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: races in from the front door. Rice and Madala drive up in Bureau's armor-plated Ford V-8.

dialogues.speaker: PURVIS
dialogues.text: They headed north! The Sheridan Road car?

dialogues.speaker: RICE
dialogues.text: That's us. We heard gunfire. So we. (gets it) .came here. They're fucked.

dialogues.speaker: MADALA
dialogues.text: Was it Dillinger?

dialogues.speaker: BAUM
dialogues.text: No. It was Lester Gillis. Purvis sinks.

dialogues.speaker: PURVIS
dialogues.text: The man we let get away wasn't John Dillinger. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was Baby Face Nelson.

dialogues.speaker: PIERPONT
dialogues.text: wearing overcoats and hats with guns tucked inside, all w into the bank. Six CUSTOMERS.

dialogues.speaker: PIERPONT
dialogues.text: Change a. twenty? Teller looks up at Pierpont but is staring into the 45 ca barrel of a Tommy gun while...

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: vaults the five foot divider railing and trains two 45s o the TELLERS.

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: Get over to the vault! Everybody! Go on! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He herds the tellers over. Pierpont makes customers sit i chairs. The vault door is already open...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: in a black Studebaker is double-parked with the engine running.

dialogues.speaker: ECU
dialogues.text: the detailed map of their getaway route.

dialogues.speaker: HOMER
dialogues.text: on Lookout watches the street. Nothing. Dillinger and Pierpont carrying canvas bags cross through the foregroun as...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: throws it into gear and they drive away. Homer jumps on t running board. Dillinger looks over his shoulder. Awestru pedestrian. From the other end of Main Street, no pursuit

dialogues.speaker: HOOVER
dialogues.text: (into phone) That was a miserable piece of work.

dialogues.speaker: PURVIS
dialogues.text: (into phone) Yes, it was. I take full responsibility, sir. Hoover calms for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: PURVIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And I'd like to request we hire part time agents with "special qualifications"... from outside the Bureau.

dialogues.speaker: HOOVER
dialogues.text: I thought you understood what I am doing...build.ing a department of professional investigators. Young college men with law or accounting degrees from good families. No, you may not go outside the Bureau, Purvis. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PURVIS
dialogues.text: The Bureau has used these men before.

dialogues.speaker: HOOVER
dialogues.text: They are not our "type."

dialogues.speaker: PURVIS
dialogues.text: Our "type" cannot get the job done... (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without qualified help I would have to resign this appointment. Otherwise, I am leading my men to slaughter. Hoover is backed against the wall. He does not like it.

dialogues.speaker: HOOVER
dialogues.text: (dead cold) Mr. Tolson will call you, Agent Purvis.

dialogues.speaker: PURVIS
dialogues.text: Thank you... (CLICK)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hoover hung up on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: has pulled into track 16. THREE MEN stand out among--,- passengers. One's face is obscured by a wide brirmdd`hat. They are --

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES WINSTEAD, CLARENCE HURT
dialogues.text: Stiff from the journey, they stretch, take in the crowd. Winstead is in his mid 40s, 5 foot 8, body out of steel cable. Hurt is in his late 30s. These men are ex-Texas Rangers. Unlike flashier Texan lawmen of the period, they not wear Western wear unless they're on a horse. That's f drugstore cowboys out to impress Easterners. They wear da suits and ties and hats. They have "special qualification

dialogues.speaker: WINSTEAD
dialogues.text: What'd he say he looked like?

dialogues.speaker: HURT
dialogues.text: Didn't say. Their suitcases have been set on the platform. A PORTER approaches.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Gentlemen need a hand? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Winstead gestures at their bags and one case. The PORTER to lift the case. It is so heavy he can barely raise it. Campbell picks up the other end. They toss it on the cart

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Hardware salesmen?

dialogues.speaker: WINSTEAD
dialogues.text: That's right. His terse reply makes the garrulous porter stop talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Neoclassical hall is enormous. Still no Purvis.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: I'll call.

dialogues.speaker: HURT
dialogues.text: I'm going to the men's room. Winstead spots a shoe-shine stand. Winstead sits, nods an the SHOE SHINE MAN begins to polish his Western boots. He startled bi:the knife in a sheath built into the right bo

dialogues.speaker: WINSTEAD
dialogues.text: Wcrk around it. From under the brim of his hat, Winstead glances at big c life in Union Station. He's an ominous presence. HEAR the excited roar of a CROWD and we --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: zips along an inside railing under the flawless Miami sky

dialogues.speaker: SLEEK GREY HOUNDS
dialogues.text: race in a pack after it under cumulous clouds and palm tr Streamline deco stands are almost filled.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK NITTI
dialogues.text: by the railing, watches the race with Phil D'An.drea. As begin to walk... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NITTI
dialogues.text: (business as usual) I want Johnny Patton out front on the other four tracks. Tell Adonis. He can have the parking concessions, and maintenance.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL D'ANDREA
dialogues.text: (NODS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annenberg wants to sell you the remaining equity in General News.

dialogues.speaker: NITTI
dialogues.text: How's he doing on the wire service?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL D'ANDREA
dialogues.text: Feeding to 300 bookies now. And he came up with this gimmick called a scratch sheet. Another beat. Nitti stops for a beat

dialogues.speaker: NITTI
dialogues.text: Its hot out, right?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL D'ANDREA
dialogues.text: Yeah, Frank.

dialogues.speaker: NITTI
dialogues.text: Ever since those pricks shot me I can't get warm. (notices Phil's attention) What?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL D' ANDREA
dialogues.text: Some friends from Chicago in the stands... D'Andrea nods. John Dillinger nods back. Nitti glances at them; glances away. Dillinger has on sunglasses. Billie is wearing a straw ha They are shouting to the greyhounds along with Pierpont, Homer and Makley and some girls. They have tall drinks. T is the good life for the privileged few in the middle of Depression. A dog wins; not theirs. It calms down...

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: (to Pierpont; business) Well drive out separately. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Billie and I want to hit the Gulf Coast on the way to Arizona.

dialogues.speaker: PIERPONT
dialogues.text: I want to take 66 and check banks in Denver and Phoenix. We'll meet you in Tucson on the 25th.

dialogues.speaker: VAN METER
dialogues.text: I think we wore out the Midwest for awhile. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard one today. Indiana paper. (LOW)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wanted. John Dillinger. Dead or...dead." (they crack up) Billie doesn't laugh. Dillinger pulls her close and she c resist his good spirits. D'Andrea's approached...

dialogues.speaker: PHIL D'ANDREA
dialogues.text: How d'ya like the track? C'mon to the Gc: -lonial for steaks tonight. (writing on a card) You be our guests...

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: Well be there.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL D'ANDREA
dialogues.text: (to cocktail waitress) Whatever these boys want, its on the house. He leaves. Pierpont, Makley and Homer go off to place new bets. Billie looks at Dillinger. Looks away. Dillinger catches her...

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: What? She is quiet for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: Thank you, thank you for these last few weeks. I never thought I'd see Florida.

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: You going somewhere, doll, am I? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: It's been, three, four weeks. You'll look for a change. Or you'll get tired of me. And then I'll be sad and angry. So I wanted to say thank you before then... Dillinger is surprised that her expectations are so low. didn't think his interest in her to be more than passing.

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: You want to leave?

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: No. But I'm no fool. I'll be back checking coats at the Steuben Club.

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: Well, I don't want you to leave. So it won't be that way.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: Then it will be another way that's worse. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You rob banks and you run rings around them, but you're likely to get killed or, get shot and...

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: Who the hell gave you a crystal ball?!

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Well, goddamn it, you don't need a crystal ball...! Ask Homer.

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: Homer what...?

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: Homer and his damn joke... I don't want to be around to see any of that. Okay?! That's what it's about... Dillinger gets it.

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: I am not going anywhere! I am going to die in your arms as an old man when that time comes. So what do you say about that?

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: Now is the first time she allows herself to have any pros about a future with him. It's a shock. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She hikes up her skirt and sits on his lap and smothers h with a kiss. Her hat falls off. Patrons nearby glance and look away. Dillinger doesn't give a damn. A new pack of dogs are about to take flight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ARIZONA)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fresh and tanned Dillinger and Billie are in a striking modern gas station on Route 66. Billie helps out a family taking their picture with a Kodak Brownie in front of a Saguaro cactus. Snow-capped Rincon mountains are behind t She leans down to play with the round baby. She looks ove Johnnie and smiles. It breaks his heart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: writing into a register. CLERK is a big man and Western friendly.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: Mr. and Mrs. Frank Sullivan of Green Bay, Wd cons in. How was your journey, sir?

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: ., ГўВЂВў ng.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: I can send up some sandwiches and beer, if you'd like.

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: That would be swell. Some friends of mine should be here already. J.C. Davies and Mr. Long?

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: Out shopping, I believe. I'll let them know you're in when they come back. Old BELLHOP takes Billie's bag to the elevator. Dillinger carries his own case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dillinger tips the bellhop a dollar. Water runs. Dillinge goes to the window - checks the street, checks for exits case of emergency.

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: You want company? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: After.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: in the tub. Dillinger enters --

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: First time you ever put me off. You getting tired of me?

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: (his answer) Get in here. She stretches out and wets her hair. She sits up to reach the shampoo. Dillinger's got it and rubs it into her hair Dillinger hears something in the street. He goes to the window and sees a car parked irregularly. TWO MEN get out

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: Get dressed. Right now. He turns and runs into...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's pulling a Tommy Gun out of his case when

dialogues.speaker: CRASH
dialogues.text: THREE MEN burst in. One is the Clerk. He cracks Dillinger across the head with the stock of his shotgun. Dillinger falls to his knees. Clerk hits him twice more. Billie rushes into the room.. She's naked. The two men fr the street haul Dillinger, bloody and semi-conscious, to feet and throw him against the wall and cuff him.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK/EYMAN
dialogues.text: Put clothes on, miss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: handcuffed is escorted through the outer cell block. He reacts. In the opposite direction in shackles

dialogues.speaker: PIERPONT
dialogues.text: escorted by six guards are being moved out of the jail. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: PIERPONT
dialogues.text: Fire in the hotel. Firemen found our guns. Laid for us! Sorry, John.

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: (shouts after them) Where they taking you?

dialogues.speaker: PIERPONT
dialogues.text: (shouts back) We're getting Shanghaied to Ohio!

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: Where's Billie...? Thenthey're gone. They now move Dillinger through.

dialogues.speaker: COP EYMAN
dialogues.text: Your girl's been put on a bus back to Chicago. We ain't holding her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: is reading "Startling Crime" magazine. He HEARS holding c outer doors opened. He looks over.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN PURVIS
dialogues.text: is there. Cowley and Baum are with him. Purvis is brought the cell. The COP who brought him goes back to his card g with four or five Tucson Deputies. We SEE Winstead and Hu in their suits and ties are there, too. They lounge at ea A Tucson Deputy gives them coffee. Eye contact with Dillinger. But Dillinger reacts to Purvis.

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER
dialogues.text: (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, the man who killed Pretty Boy Floyd. He might have been "Pretty," 'cause he sure was not "Whiz Kid Floyd." Deputies stifle laughter. Dillinger comes up close to Pur They are eyeball to eyeball. Only the bars separate them.

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER, (CONT'B)
dialogues.text: (loud, for the cop's benefit) Now these Arizona boys, here? (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They pulled on us right out. Didn't ask Washington for permission. Didn't make mistakes. Arizona Deputies enjoy the flattery. Dillinger studies Purvis...

dialogues.speaker: DILLINGER, (CONT'D)

But death and mayhem up close? I am used to that and you are not, are you? When it's toe to toe, "One of us will die right here, right now," I don't think you got the get up and go. Purvis has nothing to say. He stares at Dillinger. Then h turns to leave.

dialogues.speaker: PIQUETT
dialogues.text: (on his feet) Your honor! Are we to have a hearing in accord with the laws of this nation, or is the State to be permitted to incite an atmosphere of prejudice? The very air reeks with the bloody rancor of intolerant malice. The clanging of shackles brings to our minds the dungeons of the Czars, not the flag-bedecked liberty of an American courtroom. I request the court to direct that those shackles be removed forthwith! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE MURRAY
dialogues.text: Alright, remove the handcuffs from the prisoner.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT ESTILL

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE MURRAY
dialogues.text: Sheriff Holley?

dialogues.text: There isn't anything wrong with my jail! It's the strongest jail in Indiana.

dialogues.speaker: PIQUETT

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF HOLLEY
dialogues.text: I'm not afraid of an escape. I can take care of John Dillinger or any other prisoner.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE MURRAY

dialogues.speaker: PIQUETT

dialogues.text: To go on trial in 10 days would be a legal lynching of this lad! There's a law against lynching!

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT ESTILL
dialogues.text: There's a law against murder!

dialogues.speaker: PIQUETT
dialogues.text: Then observe the law part. Or just stand Dillinger against the wall and shoot him. Then, there's no need to throw away the State's money on this mockery.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE MURRAY
dialogues.text: (to both lawyers) Calm down.

dialogues.speaker: PIQUETT

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE MURRAY
